Visualization and simulation of 3D artificial neural structures generated by L-system
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 02 July 2009

Visualization and simulation of 3D artificial neural structures generated by L-system

  • Regina Célia Coelho1,
  • Nivaldi Calonego Jr.2 &
  • Luís Augusto Consularo3 

Virtual Reality volume 14, pages119–129(2010)Cite this article

  • 228 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • 1 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This paper presents the visualization and simulation environment of 3D artificial neural structures. A stochastic L-system has been employed to generate neural structures based on features extracted from natural cells and it takes into account an hierarchical description of each neurite to allow interactions of the users in the virtual environment built. The implemented distributed virtual reality environment has its architecture explained, as well as its user interaction features to handle virtual neural structures. Furthermore, attraction/repulsion trophic fields had their effects simulated into these virtual neural structures. This approach illustrates aspects related to the neurogenesis and neural reorganization processes regarding attractive, repulsive or both interaction fields.

Introduction

Neural cells are branched structures whose correlation between morphology and physiology are well known. However, this correlation study requires more than analytical approaches. It requires numerical simulations whose understanding could be greatly improved if simulation results were visualized and interacted by scientists or students.

Those numerical simulations can happen in several scales. For instance, modeling molecular interactions with individual neuron cells, such as neurochemical factors influencing the neuron growth; modeling the neuron signal processing, such as the potential actions in a compartmented approach; modeling lot of cells in the tissue level, where the neurons interact with each other to answer for input stimuli. An innovative approach could insert dynamical features to better understand the neuron growth conditions when its environmental circumstances change.

The place, where the neuron exists is a tissue layer whose inputs (and outputs) come from (or go to) other neurons in the same layer or from another neighbor layer. This 3D world receives branch inhabitants whose birth process (neurogenesis) and death (apoptosis) could also be simulated and consequently visualized in 3D dynamic scenes.

This paper presents a technological approach to render feasible the visualization of the numerical simulation of neuron birth, growth and death, both in the tissue level and in the neurochemical level.

Modeling and simulating neural structures have aroused the attention of neuroscience researchers (DeVaul and McCormick 1996; Mulchandani 1996; Ascoli and Krichmar 2000; Coelho and Costa 2002; Feng et al. 2005) that expect comprehend issues, such as:

  1. (i)

    The functions and connection patterns of the neural cells;

  2. (ii)

    The consequences of cells death;

  3. (iii)

    What happens if trophic field and/or chemical substances are inserted into the system;

  4. (iv)

    The influences of these elements on the neural cell plasticity.

Stochastic simulation models have been developed to encompass these requirements and artificially reproduce neural structures. Special attention must be paid to simulators dealing with realistic features performed by computer-graphic devices that provide more credible behavior, more similar to natural biological plasticity.

It is possible to find two good tools related to the visualization of neural cells: NeuronGL (Computational Neurobiology and Imaging Center (CNIC). NeuroGL 1.2,Footnote 1 and L-Neuron (Ascoli and Krichmar 2000). L-Neuron implements a stochastic L-system and a mathematical description of the topology extracted from natural cells to generate the artificial ones. However, the visual inspection of the whole cells is not enough for a simulation environment. There is the desire for:

  1. (i)

    Observing the dynamics of growth;

  2. (ii)

    Observing the interactions with models leading to an understanding of the interplay between aspects of development, such as environmental influence and the development of the whole structure;

  3. (iii)

    Simulating interactions between cells and structures;

  4. (iv)

    Diving into and following the structure growth, observing each new element being added in a non-deterministic way, forming a whole new structure;

  5. (v)

    Exploring the cell plasticity.

Although NeuronGL and L-Neuron meet several of the requirements listed above, the L-neuron method does not track the neural growth and provides at most mouse-based navigation features, such as point widgets or click buttons. NeuronGL also has mouse-based user interfaces, but with some limited 3D interaction features.

Another neural simulator is EvOL-Neuron (Nielsen et al. 2008), which uses L-system to generate candidate morphologies and evolutionary computation to guide the exploration in search for accurate morphologies. Nevertheless, the interaction environment is limited. There are still other two neural simulators: Ichikawa (Ichikawa 2005) work and NeuGen (Eberhard et al. 2006), but both with interaction environment limited. Ichikawa develops only single cell geometries with little interaction and NeuGen uses the object-oriented paradigm to generate neural networks, where each cell is generated by combining L-system with parameter sampling. NeuGen graphical interface makes the program control and the assignment of values to the configuration parameters very easy, but without option of interaction with the users.

Hence, the technique proposed here to deal with the five above listed issues is based on specialized modules as shown in Fig. 1. In this figure, the simulation environment is split into two major parts, illustrated here as two dashed-line boxes (Simulator and Viewer), where the labeled solid-line boxes represent each module and the arrowed lines denote message exchange between a pair of modules. The trophic field inclusion, whose properties influence the observed plasticity, is up to the user.

In this simulation environment it is possible to produce an animation depicting some phenomena, such as the neuron growth process. More than just observing, it can also be used to interact with the generated models, which is particularly relevant to dynamically analyzing the simulation results.

Another issue to highlight is the collaborative feature, i.e. several users interacting into the same virtual neural structure. If the users or users groups are located in different places, each one can send messages to the environment when the intention is to interact with the neural structure. For instance, a user can insert a trophic field into a neural structure and every user will see what happens with it, like a growth of some branches near the field. In a simulated simultaneity, another user can remove cells. Finally, many users can intervene and collaborate into the same virtual environment.

The Simulator module produces data without concern about a graphic system, i.e. the Simulator just performs a mathematical model, as detailed in Sect. 2. The stochastic L-system module generates the grammar rules whose sentences model both to the growth of the cells, and to the naming scheme. The naming scheme gives a name to each scene-graph node and maps these nodes into a tree structure, which yields in homogeneous namespace. The Viewer module depends on the graphic system, since it is based on a scene-graph model, as better detailed in the Sect. 3. It was developed as an application prototype to experiment with this proposed architecture whose results are discussed in the Sect. 4, and some conclusions are drawn in the Sect. 5.

The Simulator module

An abstract data type (ADT) that represents any neuron structure shall split it into parts which when put together could model it as a whole system. Hence, first of all, it is necessary to define the neuron constituent parts which are involved in that features approached by the simulation model of interest. At first glance, natural neural cells are mainly divided into soma and neuritis, where the soma is the cell body, i.e. contains the nucleus, and the neurite is any branch that comes out of the soma. The label “Tree origin” in Fig. 2 shows the region where a neurite is bound to the soma, the neurite beginning. A branch may have bifurcations, and must have, at least, one branch element and one natural end. The bifurcations can appear at several points on the branch. The natural end is each branch termination, and the branch element is either the piece between two succeeding bifurcations, or the piece between a bifurcation and a natural end, or the piece between a tree origin and a bifurcation. The neurite may have many branch elements; consequently the cell shape depends on branch element shape properties, such as color, texture, tortuosity and others. Each branch element is formed by successive parts, hereafter called compartments. This compartment division is just for the sake of modeling, where the compartment is the branch element atomic part, as shown clearly in Fig. 2. Therefore, a tortuous branch element is resultant from compartments juxtaposition according to some tortuosity shape property.

More shape properties have been included to render the virtual neuron more realistic. For instance, node or line volume features, depicted here, respectively, as spheres or cylinders (see Fig. 3a and b) can improve the information visualization about the neuron state. On the other hand, the same virtual neuron can be visualized simpler if the user wishes only to deal with features like position or length (see Fig. 3c and d). The user can switch the visualization modes according to his/her interest.

Once the visualization mode for whole cell has been chosen, the simulator module is expected to generate a data stream holding information about appearance. The data-structure traveling by this data stream could hold position and length information without appearance information. However, the interaction depends on visualization mode selection.

Therefore, the main task of the Simulator, besides to producing data, is to apply a context-free, regular, parametric and stochastic L-system to generate and define a homogeneous namespace, where each neural cell piece is specifically named. These issues are detailed in Subsects. 2.1 and 2.2, where the models based on parametric and stochastic L-system are explained, and the L-system definition is presented.

L-system definition

Parallel rewrite system or L-system was introduced by Aristid Lindenmayer in 1968 (Lindenmayer 1968) to understand and represent biological systems evolution. The L-system provides a visual and geometric interpretation for symbols and rules which results in production rules of a grammar. These production rules operate in parallel to replace that symbols related to a rule in a given grammar, similarly to biological systems, where several cells simultaneously split. L-system users are able to formally combine a number of development features of organisms together into a formal language. The string produced by iterating itself through the production rules of an L-system grammar represents the 3D hierarchical structure of organisms (plants, cells, neurons, etc.). In many cases, the question is what is the best model to describe a process evolution, while we observe it? The L-systems answers this question very appropriately since the recursive nature of its grammar make it able to produce intermediate results in discrete time, enabling it to easily represent complex objects.

The formal definition of the L-system grammar is similar to that of Chomsky grammar. Let {V, T, P, S} be the quadruple, where V ≠ {} represents the set of variable symbols, usually written as {S, F} in V. T is the set of terminal symbols which are ordinarily written as {+, −, [,]}, where T may be the empty set. The set of production rules is P ⊂ V × V*, and S ∈ V + is the axiom. L-systems are often associated to graphic interpretations of their productions, likely due to the graphic parsing mechanism thought by Prusinkiewicz (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990) to account the turtle geometry of Logo language which, in turn, has become the classic mechanism for L-systems graphic representation.

A L-system grammar example and its interpretation is presented in Fig. 4, where the meaning of each symbol is listed below:

F::

move forward and draw a line;

+::

turn right according to angle x;

−::

turn left according to angle x;

[::

pushes the current drawing state onto the stack;

]::

pops the current drawing state from the stack;

Axiom: F

Rule: F = F[−F+F]F[+F–F].

x = 20.

The diversity of L-system applications, mainly in biological fields, are easily found in the literature, which includes: plant growth (Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmayer 1990; Jacob 1995; Chen and Colomb 2003), neural growth (Hamilton 1993; McCormick and Mulchandani 1994; Coelho and Costa 2002), cell division (Boer et al. 1991) and arterial branching (Zamir 2001).

The context-free, parametric and stochastic L-system

The stochastic L-system, as the neural morphology, has a non-deterministic nature.

Therefore, it is technically possible to create neural cell models of different morphologies and simulate their development by applying the same simulation algorithm, but with different input rules and shape properties.

First, a context-free regular and parametric L-system must be defined, since it simplifies the pieces (branch elements) identification. Context-free grammars have the left hand side of a production rule formed by a single non-terminal symbol. Parametric L-systems extend the L-system original concept by associating parameters with symbols. Here, the neural structure labels (symbols) are associated with parameters so that parent symbols (left side of production rule) be able to propagate their parameters to their children (right side of rule), changing their properties. L-systems produce analogous structures to a tree data-structure and further, parametric L-systems structures can be defined by a grammar, where lower-level subtrees inherit their names from parents, resulting in a homogeneous namespace pervading the whole cell. Moreover, parametric L-systems production type can be designed and assigned to non-terminal symbols according to the parameters associated with that symbol and according to the parameters applied to produce each part name of the neural cells. In this regard, the parameters must be enclosed within parenthesis and follow their associated symbol. The main feature of stochastic L-systems use in work is that each interaction is controlled by cumulative distribution functions (CDF). For instance, a CDF based on morphological features of real neurons controls the production rules, as shown hereafter with Y rule.

The grammar presented next models a neural structure with a number of cells. It assumes that:

  • The A rules have functions to control the appearance of new cells in the neural structure;

  • The number of cells (n) is defined before starting production (the execution of rules);

  • B rules control the appearance of new neuritis;

  • The quantity of neuritis (m) is controlled by a CDF;

  • The growth of each neurite is controlled by the X rule and the bifurcation is controlled by the Y (the first bifurcation of a branch) or Z (the other bifurcation) rule;

  • The function of the Y rule is to create a bifurcation, after X or Z has defined that a bifurcation must occur;

  • The natural ends, i.e. the growth stop-condition for a branch (neurite), is controlled by the bifurcation probability of that branch. That means the branch element length, in any level, is randomly drawn before it starts growing. The neurite stops growing when the length of the branch element is reached, and there is no bifurcation at all.

$$ \begin{gathered} {\text{NT = }}\{\user2{ A,B,X,Y}\} \hfill \\ {\text{TE}} = \{ m,n,s,\varepsilon ,f,u,1,2,\left[ , \right]\} \hfill \\ {\text{PR}} = \{ \user2{A}(n) \to sn[\user2{B}(n,m)]\user2{A}(n - 1),\user2{A}\left( 0 \right) \to \varepsilon , \hfill \\ \qquad\quad\user2{ B}(n,m) \to [um\user2{X}]\user2{B}(n,m - 1),\user2{B}(n,0) \to \varepsilon , \hfill \\ \qquad\quad\user2{ X} \to uf\user2{Y},\user2{X} \to f, \hfill \\ \qquad\quad\user2{ Y} \to [1f\user2{Z}][2f\user2{Z}], \hfill \\ \qquad\quad\user2{ Z} \to \user2{Y},\user2{Z} \to \varepsilon \} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$

where NT is the set of non-terminal symbols; TE is the set of terminal symbols; and PR is the set of production rules.

The meanings of terminal symbols are:

n :

the number of cells;

s :

node identifier for a dentritic segment;

u :

underscore (‘_’). It is an identifier part of a branch element;

f :

a set of compartments which forms a branch element;

[:

pushes the state of the turtle onto the stack;

]:

pops the state of the turtle from the stack;

1, 2:

creates node identifiers. Indicates the nodes hierarchy, so that each non-leaf node descendents have a label;

ε:

means empty string. It is the branch growth termination symbol (there is no more bifurcations), or a structure termination (no more cells).

The Stochastic function

The CDFs work as natural guides to produce artificial neural cells statistically and morphologically based on natural neural cells. In this study, the cells of salamander retina had their features extracted, in order to build the CDFs. These features refer to the cells morphology, such as the compartment diameter, the neuritis quantity, the compartment length and angle, the branching (bifurcation) angle, etc. Then, statistical models for each feature were evaluated and incorporated to the L-system grammars. More details about the methodology to build these statistical models can be found in the author papers (Coelho and Costa 2002; Coelho and Jaques 2003).

The comparison between real and artificial neural structures can be achieved by analyzing the CDFs of the cells.

Once having simulated neural growth individually, neural structures are generated through the combination of several neurons and including some biological factors during the growth and formation of structures. The main emphasis is put on the spatial development. Some important factors (such as random distribution of neurons in the structure, the shape statistically similar of the natural cells, diameter of the branches, patterns of branching, etc.) have to be considered in the generation of these cells and structures, so that the result is realistic. All the branches and neurons grow simultaneously (in parallel), like the natural growth.

Using the L-system

Table 1 shows an example of the proposed grammar productions to model a small neural structure with four neural cells (n = 4). Let the axiom be A(4). Each new neuron produced by the grammar (sn, where n is the number of cells) is separated from each other by spaces in the table. In this example, the graphical result of the 11th interaction is illustrated in Fig. 5 as a continuation of the Table 1 production. In this example and in the simulation, each f generates a tortuous branch element (Coelho and Costa 2002; Coelho and Jaques 2003).

The number of neuritis (m) changes from neuron to neuron, since this number is randomly drawn according to the distribution function. So, each new neuron created, a new m number is drawn. This way, the number of neuritis drawn for the 4th neuron was 3 (m = 3); 3rd neuron was 2 (m = 2); 2nd neuron was 3 (m = 3); 1st neuron was 2 (m = 2). The bifurcation probability also obeys a distribution function. Thus, for each branch element, a number is randomly drawn according to the respective distribution function, to check if a bifurcation will happen in that branch, i.e. what Z rule (or X, in the case of the first bifurcation) will be chosen: Z → Y (or X → uf Y), which means the branch is going to bifurcate, or Z → ε_ (or X → f), which means the branch must stop growing.

In L-systems, any child branch inherits the father features (color, thickness, position, etc.) and its own features are defined by changing these inherited features. This also happens with the names of each branch, i.e. the child branch inherits the father branch name and receives an additional number to identify it. The underscores are attached to the neuron number and after neuritis number, where the numbers may have more than one digit. In the other cases, the underscore is not necessary because only the number 1 or 2 will be added to the string. This will ensure that the node name will be unique for the whole neural structure. Each neuron is positioned in the structure according to the uniform random distribution. All the somas are represented by spheres with the same radius, since the goal is to simulate realistic morphologically dendritic arborization, not realistic cellular body (soma).

This environment enables simulations, where interaction fields may be arbitrarily positioned anywhere in the neural structure, in order to investigate the effects of these interaction fields on neural cells growth. The implemented fields follow the electric field force-based equation, since it models the interaction strength (F) according to the inverse square distance:

$$ F = k*{{L}}/\left( {d^{2} } \right) $$
(1)

where k is the speed at which the dendritic arborization will approach the field (negative values mean attractive fields, and positive values mean repulsion fields); L is the distance between the current neurite dot in relation to the soma; d is the distance between the neuron dot and each field dot.

The Simulator module results are transformed into messages that are then sent to the Viewer. The Viewer uses the namespaces created by Simulator to create the scene.

The proposed grammar and the requirements as previously discussed were taken into account to define the software architecture and the interface functionalities for the visualization. There are a number of procedures for data exchange between the Simulator and the Viewer. The protocol for data exchanging between the Simulator and the Viewer modules defines a message structure with three fields: command names (Cmd), node names (NodeId) and arguments for the command (Args). All the names NodeId are sentences of the grammar shown in Table 1. Args depends on the algorithm complexity. For instance, if one assumes createSegment(String NodeId, int type, float[] color, float[] dataSet) as the whole signature, one can say that it is a call meaning “create a piece of cell, whose name is defined by the NodeId (for instance, s_3_2_121); based on the dataSet to create a geometry of some type and colored color”.

The Viewer module

The Viewer module is in charge of rendering, tracking and navigation systems. Navigation systems provide the user’s point of view or camera positioning; therefore this is not the subject of this paper. However, the user interaction with the scene is elemental to the interface between the rendering and the tracking systems, i.e. once an element has been tracked, it must be identified and has a role assigned in the graphic system. Thus, there must be a protocol between the rendering and the tracking systems enabling them to identify their objects and the respective action to be taken. The grammar, as discussed before, is the key concept for interaction, linking both the rendering and the tracking systems.

The branch element identification is done by the grammar (see Sect. 2.1), creating a unique identifier for each branch element in the whole neural system. More than that, it creates a hierarchical namespace partition, analogous to a tree data-structure, as shown in Fig. 5. Such data-structure is called scene-graph. Several rendering systems make use of scene-graphs to draw the images in the visualization device, because it may speed up the rendering task. Besides that, scene-graphs provide a structured way to query the graphic information about any branch element. The namespace, i.e. the branch element unique identification, leaves to gather and change its graphic properties. Moreover, since a branch element is a set of 3D points, given a 3D triple, any branch element can be searched simply by pursuing the scene-graph. Recovering the associated identifier from the 3D point is the fundamental building block for collision-detection. As explained before, the entire branch element label will look like the template “somaId_branchId_branchElementId”, where:

“somaId” is a string of digits which identifies a cell;

“branchId” is a string of digits which identifies the first branch element (neurite) in the cell;

“branchElementId” is a string of digits which identifies the ith level of a given “branchId”. For instance, assuming the first level as the “level 0” and a function sizeOf(a) which returns the number of characters of a, one can say that the level of the branch element is the sizeOf(branchElementId), as illustrated in Fig. 6. Although the “somaId_branchId_” may have several characters, it represents only one neurite, i.e. the first level of branch element.

The representation illustrated in Fig. 6 makes the interaction easier, because dealing with the nodes in the scene-graph is analogous to a binary search tree, where its elements are strings. Handling strings of identifiers with same size means working on a given level of cells. The signal propagation simulation, for instance the action potential, gains with this approach as well as the visualization tasks, such as cells coloring.

Experiments and results

Distributed virtual reality systems also enable geographically distributed users work together in a virtual environment shared through a computer network to solve problems in a collaborative way. In this paper, the distributed system developed here renders support for working teams searching mutual collaboration and cooperation, affording the team participants to interact with the neural structure while its production, or to produce new neural structures. The block diagram in Fig. 7 shows how the modules are logically connected. User’s interactions module is the cooperative environment core, since the interaction commands can directly be sent to the Server module or broadcasted over the network by the Proxy module. In summary, the Simulator is a data producer whose data transfers are negotiated with the Proxy module. The Proxy transforms the data into object parts (in general, compartments) and sends it to the Server. The Server runs the Interaction module, which parses the commands to handle the objects in the scene rendered by OpenVRML procedures. In this case, the Proxy transforms the data input in commands to output the VRML code, by meeting the code templates in the Proxy.

The VRML code produced by the Proxy has their nodes named according to the previously discussed grammar. These labels are applied to cause changes in the scene, for instance rotation, translation, and scale transform, among others. Furthermore, this naming process also leaves to change the shape of the cells, by selecting different geometries, such as dots, lines, spheres or extrusion (Fig. 3). After the scene has been created, the colors or transparency levels can be changed.

In all these cases, the grammar provides a homogeneous way of dealing with the each neuron piece in the scene. Moreover, the simulation is a loosely-coupled distributed system running on a computer network, where each machine handles the same dataset, but rendering different geometric properties. The “App_1”, “App_2”, “App_n”, as illustrated in Fig. 7, show different instances of the same application, i.e. the same code running on different machines. Each one of these applications has its own point of view, defined by different camera positioning individually assigned to each user. The camera positioning is managed by the ARToolkit (Kato and Billinghurst 1999; Kato et al. 2000) working as a position user tracker which sends the positioning parameters to the Navigation module.

The Proxy module

The Proxy module between the Simulator and the Viewer manages their message exchanges. By observing the Fig. 1, a set of Proxy functionalities can be explored, since a Proxy instance can exchange messages with several instances of the Viewer module (see Fig. 8). Hence, each instance of the Proxy module, labeled as Pi in Fig. 8, has its own configuration file, and controls the Viewer module Vij instance. This approach leaves the user to check the qualitative visualization properties enabling users to see simultaneous different points of view.

In fact, the Proxy module connects modules whose architecture requirements could be summarized into three premises:

  1. (i)

    How the user sees the cells, not only the shape of the cells but their appearance;

  2. (ii)

    Navigation must not change the geometry or appearance of any objects in the scene;

  3. (iii)

    Interaction may modify attributes, add or remove objects from the scene.

For example, the navigation command requires the user point of view. In this case, the dashed-line in Fig. 8 illustrates this local feedback for each Vij. However, collaborative works needs sharing the user point of view with other users. The Proxy also manages the requisitions of users in collaborative activities, such as save some neural structure state, or multicast user messages. Moreover, it must support not only internal commands, but also commands which may be distributed to the viewers, as illustrated by the dotted line in Fig. 8.

Interactions

The structure resultant from this proposed branch naming can be pursued either by a tree, or a linear structure. When an event has to be propagated from a node to its descendants (for instance, to reach a whole neurite), the tree structure is more suitable. In the other side, an event which happens in specific node is more suitably accessed by linear structures because of their random access nature. The neuron edition activity often demands revisions in the dendritic arborization, which may cause changes in the geometry of the whole cell. If each node change does not impact any other node, then the linear structure is the best structure.

The user deals with a rich interaction environment which he/she can edit, or interact or execute the neural structure after the simulator had produced it.

The neuritis or cells can be colored to improve the visualization experience, mainly when a cell is not visible because of occlusion caused by other objects very close to it. Alternatively, one or more cells can become slightly or completely transparent. The last case is the same to hide one or more cells (or neuritis) to visualize some occluded neural structure or just specific cells. Figure 9 illustrates the coloring, where the tree structure is more suitable, since every node related to the interest cell was colored. Consequently, some cells became transparent and the interest cell was colored.

Another relevant interaction feature is the insertion of trophic field. According to Perry and Maffei (1988), the sprouting of some chemotrophic factors can lead to neural reorganization. This visualization approach leaves to introduce several fields, either attraction or repulsion fields, with different strengths in the same structure. Supposing that each field emulates a new chemotrophic factor sprouting into the structure, analysis about what will happen to the cells could be done, even if the present fields had their strengths changed, or different fields were introduced into the neural structures.

The reorganization caused by inserting a trophic field into the structure implies a new position computation for each node, which depends on its field distance (the closer the distance, the larger the field influence) and its soma distance (the stronger the distance, the larger the field influence), as seen in Eq. (1).

Figure 10 illustrates the steps of the neural structure reorganization after the trophic fields were inserted. By observing Fig. 10b and c, the dendritic arborization was reorganized in the direction of the attraction field. Figure 10d shows a major dendritic arborization reorganization going to the attraction field in the top of the structure; that occurred after a repulsion field had been inserted at the bottom of the neural structure, which resulted in the repulsion of dendritic arborization to the new trophic field.

Conclusions

A number of virtual neural cells have been built and some of these models have contributed to a better understanding of their morphology, consequently explaining better the mechanisms of neural cells growth. Virtual neurons are essential in computational neuroscience to study the relation between neuronal form and function. The neural cells simulation is an essential tool to support studies about the neural structure development, neural plasticity, neurogenesis and signal interaction among different neural cells. However, the visualization of neural cell simulation results is still incipient. Neuroscientists could have new insights about natural neurons if their assumptions could be more than numerically simulated and analyzed, but numerically simulated, visualized and analyzed, even in real time.

An important benefit of computational simulation of neural growth is that direct visual observation and manipulation of three-dimensional neural structures helps the development of novel intuitions among researchers, besides allowing a better basic understanding among students.

This paper introduced an L-system in order to describe the growth of neural structures, not just single cells, as it is more commonly found. This L-system allows several cells—with many neuritis—to grow together at the same time (in parallel). Moreover, cumulative distribution functions (CDFs) have guided the development of L-systems and modulated some morphological measurements of each generated cell (for instance, the number of neurite, the neurite length, and the neurite rotation). It was implemented commands to support neural structure edition, which enable the user to build different types of neural cells (as described by respective CDFs), and include them in simulation experiments. The L-system structured approach to build neural structures provided a hierarchical description of each neurite, which have become feasible for the interactions and simulations.

The Viewer module, whose main task is the visual reorganization of information produced by the Simulator, has been implemented; which allows the user to handle the virtual neural structure. The user interaction with the neural structures is essential to dynamically analyze the neural structures development. A number of interactions were coded in the Viewer, such as point of view selection, geometric transformations, insert/remove trophic fields, coloring, transparency, hiding, etc.

Mechanisms controlling the reorganization processes influenced by chemotrophic factors are not well known. The Viewer and the Simulator afforded this investigation, since the effects of the inclusion of several trophic fields into the neural structure, i.e. the neural cells arborization reorganization, can be reproduced according new parameters. Hence, modeling and simulating the reorganization processes can provide invaluable insights into their underlying mechanisms.

The approach described in this paper has opened new possibilities for modeling and simulating morphologically more realistic neural networks, and, mainly, for interacting with this structure. By using a suitable set of shape measures of natural cells with the L-system it is possible to generate artificial cells presenting morphological characteristics close to those of natural cells. This is particularly important since it allows a new approach to investigate the relationship between neural shape and function, with the additional advantage that all the morphological information about the produced structures is accurately known and can be clearly visualized and studied.

In this paper simplified models of neural cells was adopted, without concern about the precise modeling of these cells, since this modeling involves a considerable array of factors not regarded in these simulations. These simplified models have afforded the analysis of neural growth processes and their reorganization influenced by the trophic fields.

The trophic field can also be useful to control the dendrites growth, since in nature the dendrites can be influenced by inhibitory and/or excitatory trophic fields during their growth (van Oss and van Ooyen 1997). This feature will be regarded in future implementation.

Future implementations will also include the neural death. During the formation of the mammalian nervous system, an excess of neural cells is produced. Due to this, there is natural death of some cells and this is essential for the correct functional and structural maturation of the nervous system (Clarke 1985). It has been verified that after neural death has occurred in a young animal, a reorganization of the cells takes place (Perry and Linden 1982). These are typical processes (neural death and neural reorganization) which this proposed work can be useful to provide new insights.
